    Two Pointers Method
    The Two Pointers Method is an important technique that is often used in competetive programming.

    What is this method? The easiest way to explain it is with the example of the task "Merging two sorted arrays".

    What is this task? We are given two arrays, sorted in ascending order, aa and bb. We want to combine the elements of these arrays into one big array cc, also sorted in ascending order.

    The easiest way to do this is with the following algorithm:

    1. collect all the elements into one big array;
    2. sort it with any sorting built into your language.

    Such an algorithm will take time O(n⋅log(n))O(n⋅log(n)).

    In this step, we will learn how to do it simply, without sorting, and in time faster than O(n⋅log(n))O(n⋅log(n)) (in linear time).

    Let's see an example. We are given two arrays:

    a=[1,3,5,8,10]a=[1,3,5,8,10]
    b=[2,6,7,9,13]b=[2,6,7,9,13]

    How do we merge them into one sorted array? To answer this question, let's understand which element will be in the first position in this array. Of course, this is the smallest element among all in aa and bb. In array aa, the minimum element is the first (since the array is sorted). The situation is similar in array bb.

    Let's look at these two elements (the first in aa and bb), select the minimum one and move it to the first position in array cc .

    a=[/1,3,5,8,10]a=[⧸1,3,5,8,10]
    b=[2,6,7,9,13]b=[2,6,7,9,13]
    c=[1]c=[1]

    Now let's look again at the first non-deleted element of array aa and the first non-deleted element of array bb. They are the smallest ones remaining in their arrays. Let's choose the smaller of these two elements and transfer it to cc.

    a=[/1,3,5,8,10]a=[⧸1,3,5,8,10]
    b=[/2,6,7,9,13]b=[⧸2,6,7,9,13]
    c=[1,2]c=[1,2]

    We will continue this algorithm until all the elements in aa and bb are removed.

    How to implement this? You need to create two pointers (this where the name of the method is from).

    The first pointer will point to the first non-deleted element in aa, and the second pointer to the first non-deleted element in bb.

    a=[/1,3i↓,5,8,10]a=[⧸1,3i↓,5,8,10]
    b=[/2,6j↑,7,9,13]b=[⧸2,6j↑,7,9,13]
    c=[1,2]c=[1,2]

    Each time we look, which of the elements under the pointers is smaller. If it is from the array aa, then you need to transfer it. Otherwise, you need to transfer an element from array bb. The index of the transfered element in array cc will always be i+ji+j. After we have moved the element, the corresponding pointer needs to be shifted to the right.

    while i < a.size() || j < b.size():
        if a[i] < b[j]:
           c[i + j] = a[i]
           i++
        else:
           c[i + j] = b[j]
           j++

    In the implementation of the algorithm, you need to be careful, at some point the elements of one of the arrays will run out completely, but in the other array the elements will still remain. For example, at the end of the algorithm with our example, we come to the following situation:

    a=[/1,/3,/5,/8,/10]i↓a=[⧸1,⧸3,⧸5,⧸8,⧸10]i↓
    b=[/2,/6,/7,/9,13j↑]b=[⧸2,⧸6,⧸7,⧸9,13j↑]
    c=[1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10]c=[1,2,3,5,6,7,8,9,10]

    If you do not implement the algorithm carefully, then at the next check which of the pointers is on the smallest element, you will go beyond the boundaries of the array.

    There are two ways to solve this problem.

    The first is to add +∞+∞ to the end of each of the arrays (in your programming language, this is the maximum number that fits into the data type).

    Second solutions is to write the condition more accurately. When do you need to transfer an element from the first array? In case the second array has ended completely or if the first array has not ended yet and the element in it is less than the element in array bb . The second case is dealt with in a similar way.

    while i < a.size() || j < b.size():
        if j == b.size() || i < a.size() && a[i] < b[j]:
           c[i + j] = a[i]
           i++
        else:
           c[i + j] = b[j]
           j++
    Why does this work in linear time? Each time we move one of the two pointers forward. The first pointer will be shifted no more times than the size of array aa, and the second no more than the size of array bb. In total, the algorithm will make O(a.size()+b.size())O(a.size()+b.size()) operations.
    Number of smaller
    Let's apply the same technique to solve a different problem.

    We have two arrays aa and bb. We want to calculate for each element bjbj how many such ii exist that ai<bjai<bj.

    This is a fairly common task, often encountered on a variety of occasions.

    How to solve it? First, let's sort both arrays (if initially they were given unsorted). Now you can use binary search to answer the problem (we covered it in another chapter). For each element of bb, you need to find the prefix of array aa that is less than this element.

    But you can do without binary search by using the two pointer method. Suppose we are doing the same merge sort as in the previous task. We will get a large sorted array cc containing all the elements from aa and bb.

    How to solve the problem using the resulting array cc? Let's see to which position of cc element bjbj moved. Where are the elements of array aa that are less than bjbj? They are in cc to the left of bjbj. Therefore, you need to find out how many elements came from array aa on the prefix of array cc before the element bjbj.

    For implementation, you can use the same algorithm as in the previous task. Array cc itself is not useful to us. Let's take a look at the moment when we move an element from array bb. How many elements from aa were moved before it? These are all elements with indices from 00 to i−1i−1 (ii is a pointer to the first non-deleted element in aa). That is, there are exactly ii such elements.

    We no longer need to move elements into array cc. We simply move the pointers forward and respond to requests during the "former" moving of elements from bb.

    while ...:
        if ...:
           i++
        else:
           res[j] = i
           j++

    Also, in this task, you can write simpler and more intuitive code. Instead of a single while loop with conditions inside, you can loop over the elements of array bb (loop over the position of the jj pointer). And with the second for loop move the first pointer ii forward while ai<bjai<bj. 

    i = 0
    for j = 0..b.size()-1:
        while i < a.size() && a[i] < b[j]:
           i++
        res[j] = i

        I don't know if its better or not but since its in 2-pointer lesson here's a 2-pointer approach- you can first pick as many elements (starting from maximum costs) as you can from array a. After this start taking elements from array b (starting from maximum costs) and if current weight goes beyond S then start removing element from array a till current weight becomes less than S. At each point when weight is less than S just update the answer.

        jeroenodb
        4 weeks ago, # ^ |
          +1

        Hey, my approach for Segment with the Required Subset was: I used the two stacks trick that was in the tutorials. Now we only have to recalculate the subset sum when we add an element. We can store the intermediate DP-table of a subset sum as a bitset of size 1001, where b[i] means that you can reach sum i. Then if you add an element to the set, the bitset gets updated like: b = (b | b<<val). . Last thing left is to check if current segment is good. We have to merge the top bitset of the first and second stack. This can be done with the bitset and-operation. Only then you have to store one of the bitsets backwards, so the elements line up. The runtime will be

        O(n⋅smaxwordsize)O(n⋅smaxwordsize)

        In the first problem you can't take the same element twice. The playlist will always go to the next song.

    Could someone help me with Problem F of Step 2 (I fail on test case 3)? My idea is to maintain an increasing and decreasing sequence of numbers which will allow me to find updates quickly. When I reach a new maximum, I update the minimum so that (max — min) becomes at most k. Similarly for the case when I reach a new minimum. Any help would be really appreciated, thanks!

    Code
    #include <bits/stdc++.h>

constexpr bool test_cases = false;

void solve () {
    int64_t n, k;
    std::cin >> n >> k;
    std::vector <int64_t> a (n);
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i)
        std::cin >> a [i];

    int index = 0;
    int min   = a [index];
    int max   = a [index];
    std::deque <int> asc;
    std::deque <int> dsc;
    int64_t ans = 1;

    asc.push_back(0);
    dsc.push_back(0);

    for (int i = 1; i < n; ++i) {
        while (!asc.empty() && a [asc.back()] > a [i])
            asc.pop_back();
        while (!dsc.empty() && a [dsc.back()] < a [i])
            dsc.pop_back();

        asc.push_back(i);
        dsc.push_back(i);

        if (a [i] > max) {
            max = a [i];
            if (max - min > k) {
                while (max - a [asc.front()] > k)
                    asc.pop_front();
                index = asc.front();
                min   = a [index];
                while (dsc.front() < index)
                    dsc.pop_front();
            }
        }
        else if (a [i] < min) {
            min = a [i];
            if (max - min > k) {
                while (a [dsc.front()] - min > k)
                    dsc.pop_front();
                index = dsc.front();
                max   = a [index];
                while (a [asc.front()] < index)
                    asc.pop_front();
            }
        }

        ans += i - index + 1;
    }

    std::cout << ans << '\n';
}

int main () {

    std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
    std::cin.tie(nullptr);

    int32_t cases = 1;
    if (test_cases)
        std::cin >> cases;
    while (cases--)
        solve();

    return 0;
}

          morty
          3 weeks ago, # ^ |
            0

          We may need to listen to playlist multiple times, so we calculate the number of times we need to listen the complete playlist, then the remaining points needed will be p % sum. Now we only need to find the smallest segment with points at least p % sum. Segment may be a suffix plus a prefix, a convenient way to do this is to copy array at the end.

    What is wrong with this code I am getting wrong answer on test case 40.Please anyone help

    import java.io.BufferedWriter; import java.io.OutputStreamWriter; import java.util.Scanner;

    public final class Codeforces {

    public static long min(long[] arr) {
    long mn = arr[0];
    for (int i = 1; i < arr.length; i++) {
        if (mn > arr[i]) {
            mn = arr[i];
        }
    }
    return mn;
}

public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    BufferedWriter bw = new BufferedWriter(new OutputStreamWriter(System.out));
    Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);
    int n = sc.nextInt();
    long sum = sc.nextLong();
    long[] arr = new long[n];
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        arr[i] = sc.nextLong();
    }
    // Condition for no possible segment
    if (sum < min(arr)) {
        bw.write("0\n");
    } else {
        int l1 = 0;
        int ans = 0;
        long currSum = 0;
        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
            currSum = currSum + arr[i];
            while (currSum >= sum) {
                currSum = currSum - arr[l1];
                ++l1;
            }
            ans = Math.max(ans, i - l1 + 1);
        }
        bw.write(ans + "\n");
    }
    sc.close();
    bw.flush();
}

    }

    codeacpc

    ← Rev. 2 →   0

    This code fails on tc 49 of STEP-3 Looped Playlist. What ain't right?

    Solution

    n, s = map(int, input().split()) arr = list(map(int, input().split())) total = sum(arr) times = s//total s = s % total n *= 2 arr.extend(arr)

    left, right, tot, ans = 0, 0, 0, 2000000 idx = 0 for i in range(0, n, 1): tot += arr[i]

    while tot >= s and left <= i:
    if i - left + 1 < ans:
        ans = i - left + 1

        idx = left
    tot -= arr[left]
    left += 1

    print(idx+1, int(times*(n/2)+(ans if times!=1 else 0)))

    #include<bits/stdc++.h>
#define endl "\n" 
using namespace std;
#define debug(x) cout<<"The value of "<<#x<<" is "<<x<<endl;
typedef long long ll;
typedef unsigned long long ull;
 
int main()
{
    cin.sync_with_stdio(0); cin.tie(0); 
    ll n,c;
    cin>>n>>c;
    string s;
    cin>>s;
    ll ans=-1e9,l=0;
    ll aValues=0,bValues=0;
    ll currentRudness=0;
    for(ll r=0;r<n;r++){
        if(s[r]=='a')aValues++;
        else if(s[r]=='b'){
            bValues++;
            currentRudness+=aValues;
        }
        while(currentRudness>c){
            // now move the left pointer to right as lond as rudeness is more than c
            if(s[l]=='a')currentRudness-=bValues;
            else if(s[l]=='b')bValues--;
            l++;
        }
        //now rudeness is less than c, check with max value
        ans=max(ans,r-l+1);
    }
    cout<<ans<<endl;
}

              nipul1
              2 weeks ago, # ^ |
              ← Rev. 2 →   0

              I have used segment tree for calculating gcd of a range.

              suppose you know the gcd of a range [l, r] (let it be gc) and you want to extend your range to [l, r+1] then you can calculate it by finding gcd of gc, and a[r+1].

              now while moving left pointer it is difficult to recalculate gcd, using previous gcd values. that can be done by querying the segment tree for range [l+1, r]

              I Hope it is clear !!

    Two pointer Step 3 : Looped Playlist

    Approach : 

    n = array size  
appending copy of array v to itself  
new array size = 2 * n  
times = dividing target by sum of element of new array  
new target = target % (sum of element of new array)  
if new target == 0:  
  print 1 and 2 * n * times  
  return  
use 2 pointer to find smallest subset of new array whose sum is greater than or equal to new target  
 maintain length, and index   
print index  
and  
print no of song = 2 * n * times + length

    But i'm get WA on testcase 31
    where i'm making a mistake 

    int main() {
  ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(NULL);
  cout.tie(NULL);

  ll n, target;
  cin >> n >> target;
  vii v; re(v, n); // reading in vector
  rep(i,0,n) v.push_back(v[i]);

  rep(i,1,2 * n) v[i] += v[i - 1];
  ll times = target / v[2 * n - 1];
  target = target % v[2 * n - 1];

  if (target == 0) {
    cout << 1 << " " << 2 * n * times;
    return 0;
  }

  int id  = 0;
  int len = 2 * n + 1;

  for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < 2 * n; i++) {
    ll tmp = v[i];
    if (j) tmp -= v[j];
    while (tmp >= target) {
      if ((i - j + 1) < len) len = i - j + 1, id = j;
      j++;
      tmp = v[i] - v[j - 1];
    }
  }
  cout << id + 1 << " " << 2 * n * times + len;
}

      yeah! I used the same algorithm that was used in the F in the lectures. by using two stacks to maintain a queue. I remove the elements from the left stack and add on the right stack and on each side, I maintained a gcd stack which gives me the gcd of the elements currently pushed into the side stack. You can understand if you think of it as a queue and the stacks are used for storing the gcd.

    [SPOILER ALERT] Easy AC solution for the problem "Segment with the Required Subset"

    While iterate over the input array, you should maintain an array C of length s where: C[j] is the maximum index of the beginning subsequence whose sum is equal to j.

    k = 0 # this is the second pointer
C = [-1 for i in range(s)]
ans = int('inf')
# Iterate the array with the first pointer
for i in range(0, n, 1):
    # Update C array
    for j in range(s, a[i], -1):
        C[j] = max(C[j], C[j-a[i]])
    C[a[i]] = i
  
    if C[s] >= k:
        ans = min(ans, i - C[s] + 1)
        k = C[s] + 1

print(ans if ans < int('inf') else -1)

    Complexity is the sum of array My submission:

    #include <bits/stdc++.h>
//#include <boost/multiprecision/cpp_int.hpp>
//using boost::multiprecision::cpp_int;
 
using namespace std;
#define ll long long int
#define ul unsigned long int
#define mod 1000000007
#define care                          \
    ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false); \
    cin.tie(NULL), cout.tie(NULL);
 
 ll mulmod(ll a, ll b) 
{ 
    ll res = 0; // Initialize result 
    a = a % mod; 
    while (b > 0) 
    { 
        // If b is odd, add 'a' to result 
        if (b % 2 == 1) 
            res = (res + a) % mod; 
  
        // Multiply 'a' with 2 
        a = (a * 2) % mod; 
  
        // Divide b by 2 
        b /= 2; 
    } 
  
    // Return result 
    return res % mod; 
} 
 
int main()
{
#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE

    freopen("output.txt", "w", stdout);
#endif

        cin>>v1[i];

    for(int j=0;j<m;j++){
        cin>>v2[j];

            if(res2.find(it->first)!=res2.end()){
